theory.description: Principios y conocimientos del Goju Ryu

theory.philosophyDesc: Principios fundamentales y valores del Goju Ryu

videoError.title: Las demostraciones en video estarán visibles en la aplicación móvil
videoError.pathError: No se pudo cargar el video desde: {{path}}
videoError.instructions: Por favor, asegúrese de que los archivos MP4 estén colocados en el directorio public/Video/Blocks con estos nombres de archivo:

ageUke.name: Age Uke
ageUke.description: Una técnica de bloqueo que desvía un ataque hacia arriba y protege la cara y la parte superior del cuerpo.

gedanBarai.name: Gedan Barai
gedanBarai.description: Un bloqueo de barrido que desvía ataques a la parte inferior del cuerpo.

sotoUke.name: Soto Uke
sotoUke.description: Un bloqueo que desvía un ataque de adentro hacia afuera.

uchiUke.name: Uchi Uke
uchiUke.description: Un bloqueo que desvía un ataque de afuera hacia adentro.

shutoUke.name: Shuto Uke
shutoUke.description: Un bloqueo realizado con el lateral de la mano.

empiUke.name: Empi Uke
empiUke.description: Un bloqueo realizado con el codo.

kosaUke.name: Kosa Uke
kosaUke.description: Un bloqueo realizado con las muñecas cruzadas.

jujiUke.name: Juji Uke
jujiUke.description: Un bloqueo realizado con los brazos cruzados en forma de X.

haiwanUke.name: Haiwan Uke
haiwanUke.description: Un bloqueo realizado con la parte posterior del antebrazo.

practice.techniquesDesc: Aprende las técnicas fundamentales del Goju Ryu
practice.hojoUndoDesc: Métodos y herramientas de entrenamiento suplementario

study.description: Lecciones interactivas y cuestionarios para profundizar tus conocimientos
study.quizDesc: Pon a prueba tus conocimientos sobre varios temas.
study.flashcardDesc: Repasa términos y conceptos con tarjetas de memoria.
study.noFlashcards: No hay conjuntos de tarjetas de memoria disponibles actualmente.

settings.title: Configuración
settings.description: Personaliza tu experiencia en la aplicación

theory.title: [ES] Teoría del Kata
theory.description: [ES] Comprender los principios y la práctica del kata

sanchin.description: El kata más fundamental de Goju Ryu. Se centra en la respiración adecuada, la postura y la tensión en todo el cuerpo. Las 'tres batallas' se refieren a la mente, el cuerpo y el espíritu.
sanchin.history: Significa literalmente 'tres batallas'. No se refiere a una pelea real, sino a la lucha interna para fortalecer el cuerpo, la mente y el espíritu mediante la fuerza de voluntad. El kata consiste en técnicas lentas realizadas con tensión muscular continua y respiración abdominal profunda. El Sanchin moderno es una variante desarrollada por Miyagi Chojun sensei (fundador, 1888-1953) basada en el original transmitido por Higaonna Kanryo sensei. La respiración en la versión original era más explosiva y el cuerpo giraba dos veces 180 grados. Los estudiantes avanzados pueden ser probados en la tensión muscular correcta durante Sanchin por otros estudiantes, que verifican la ejecución sintiendo y golpeando ciertas partes del cuerpo. Esta prueba se llama shime. Material de examen para gokyu (quinto kyu, cinturón verde) y superior.
sanchin.culturalSignificance: Sanchin se considera la esencia del karate Goju Ryu, encarnando los principios de respiración, postura y concentración que son centrales en el estilo.

tensho.description: Significa literalmente 'palmas giratorias'. Este kata fue desarrollado por Miyagi Chojun sensei como contraparte de Sanchin. Al igual que Sanchin, se realiza con respiración profunda y tensión muscular general, pero su carácter es muy diferente. Mientras que Sanchin es cerrado, angular y duro (go), Tensho es abierto, elegante y suave (ju), con muchas técnicas circulares de manos y muñecas. Material de examen para sandan (tercer dan) y superior.
tensho.history: Creado por Chojun Miyagi como contraparte de Sanchin, Tensho representa el aspecto suave y circular del Goju Ryu.
tensho.culturalSignificance: Tensho demuestra el lado 'ju' (suave) del Goju Ryu, complementando el 'go' (duro) de Sanchin.

gekisai-dai-ichi.description: Uno de los dos kata Gekisai creados por Chojun Miyagi para la educación física en las escuelas. Enseña técnicas fundamentales y patrones de respiración en un formato más simple que los kata antiguos.
gekisai-dai-ichi.history: Significa literalmente 'atacar y destruir 1'. Este nombre inusualmente agresivo para el karate refleja la época en que Okinawa era un campo de batalla para acciones de guerra japonesas y estadounidenses. El kata fue desarrollado en 1940 por el fundador del Goju-ryu Karate-do de Okinawa, Miyagi Chojun sensei. Consiste en varias combinaciones de técnicas básicas simples, que facilitan el aprendizaje de los kata clásicos más difíciles. Material de examen para kukyu (noveno kyu, cinturón blanco) y superior.
gekisai-dai-ichi.culturalSignificance: Este kata fue parte del esfuerzo de Miyagi para popularizar el karate y hacerlo accesible a una audiencia más amplia, especialmente a la generación más joven.

gekisai-dai-ni.description: El segundo de los dos kata Gekisai. Se basa en las técnicas de Gekisai Dai Ichi con movimientos adicionales y patrones ligeramente más complejos.
gekisai-dai-ni.history: Significa literalmente 'atacar y destruir 2'. Al igual que Gekisai Dai Ichi, desarrollado por Miyagi Chojun sensei por las mismas razones. Material de examen para nanakyu (séptimo kyu, cinturón amarillo) y superior.
gekisai-dai-ni.culturalSignificance: Representa la evolución de la instrucción de karate a medida que se estandarizaba para una enseñanza más amplia.

saifa.description: Un kata que enfatiza los cambios rápidos de dirección y las técnicas a corta distancia. Contiene movimientos de agarre, tracción y desgarro diseñados para el combate cercano.
saifa.history: Significa algo así como 'golpes destructivos'. 'Sai' significa, como en Gekisai, 'destruir'. 'Fa' significa, entre otras cosas, 'golpear'. Típico de Saifa son las muchas técnicas de golpeo, como uraken uchi, tettsui uchi y haito uchi. Saifa es el primer kata clásico koryu. El kata fue transmitido por Ryu Ryu Ko a Higaonna Kanryo sensei. En comparación con los kata Gekisai Dai, a partir de Saifa la dificultad aumenta y aparecen cada vez más combinaciones de técnicas de mano y pie que requieren buena coordinación. Material de examen para gokyu (quinto kyu, cinturón verde) y superior.
saifa.culturalSignificance: Saifa representa la evolución de las técnicas de artes marciales diseñadas para situaciones prácticas de autodefensa en entornos concurridos.

bunkai.title: [ES] Bunkai
bunkai.description: [ES] Application and analysis of kata techniques

gekisaiDaiIchi.title: [ES] Gekisai Dai Ichi Bunkai
gekisaiDaiIchi.description: [ES] Literally means 'attack and destroy 1'. This unusually aggressive name for karate reflects the era when Okinawa was a battlefield for Japanese-American war actions. The kata was developed in 1940 by the founder of Okinawa Goju-ryu Karate-do, Miyagi Chojun sensei. It consists of various combinations of simple basic techniques, which facilitate learning the later, more difficult classical koryu kata.

bunkai1.name: [ES] Jodan Age Uke + Jodan Oi Zuki
bunkai1.footwork: [ES] 45° diagonal step back to Heiko Sanchin Dachi + foot switch (in-out).
bunkai1.notes: [ES] Always maintain Zanchin. This applies to all bunkai!

bunkai2.name: [ES] Gedan Harai Uke
bunkai2.defense: [ES] Gedan Harai Uke (as strike and block simultaneously).
bunkai2.footwork: [ES] Sideways step outward into Shiko Dachi.
bunkai2.notes: [ES] When training with hard contact, do not attack the vital point [Hijitsume] but the forearm!

bunkai3.name: [ES] Chudan Yoko Uke + Mae Geri + Hiji Ate + Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai3.counterAttack: [ES] Gedan Mae Geri + Chudan Hiji Ate + Jodan Uraken Uchi.
bunkai3.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin + after Mae Geri step forward into Zenkutsu Dachi.
bunkai3.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. [Kinteki] (Mae Geri) + [Ganka] or [Suigetsu] (Hiji Ate) + [Jinchu] (Jodan Uraken Uchi).
bunkai3.notes: [ES] The low front kick is executed with the ball of the foot, the front of the ankle, or the shin depending on the distance. The attacker evades the Chudan Hiji Ate with a backward Suri Ashi.

bunkai4.name: [ES] Gedan Harai Uke + Chudan Gyaku Zuki
bunkai4.notes: [ES] Advanced students (from brown belt) must practice the block and counter-attack as one movement. The last two Bunkai Kumite must also be trained as one unit by advanced students.

bunkai5.name: [ES] Ashi Barai + Yoko Shuto Uchi + Hikite + Fumikomi Geri
bunkai5.counterAttack: [ES] Ashi Barai + Yoko Shuto Uchi + Fumikomi Geri.
bunkai5.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. [Jinchu] or Adam's apple [Nodo Botoku] (Yoko Shuto Uchi) + neck (Fumikomi Geri).
bunkai5.notes: [ES] Quickly return the foot after Ashi Barai to prevent the opponent from attacking your leg. For the opponent's safety, the Yoko Shuto Uchi is not executed as a strike to a Kyusho, but more as a push to the chest and shoulder. The Fumikomi Geri can be executed with either leg, depending on how the opponent falls. However, in the Kata it is the same leg as the one used for the sweep. Advanced karateka can also make an irimi step and sweep the opponent from close range. In this advanced variation, the elbow is also locked on the chest.

bunkai6.name: [ES] Awase Zuki
bunkai6.defense: [ES] Nagashi Seiken Ura Uke (variant of Chudan Yoko Uke).
bunkai6.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin + step into Zenkutsu Dachi.
bunkai6.notes: [ES] The attack must be intercepted early. The Awase Zuki must first be powerfully focused before continuing as a push. To do this, you must first relax inward and downward and let the breath come in. The Awase Zuki is a miniaturized, closed-hand version of the Tora Guchi.

gekisaiDaiNi.title: [ES] Gekisai Dai Ni Bunkai
gekisaiDaiNi.description: [ES] Literally means 'attack and destroy 2'. Like Gekisai Dai Ichi, developed by Miyagi Chojun sensei for the same reasons. The kata consists of various combinations of simple basic techniques, which facilitate learning the later, more difficult classical koryu kata.

bunkai1.name: [ES] Hiki Uke
bunkai1.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. Adam's apple [Nodo Botoke] and/or carotid artery [Matsukaze].
bunkai1.notes: [ES] When slipping in (Suri Ashi), hook the front foot around the attacker's front foot and apply a leg lock, or place your front foot on the attacker's front foot. Lock the attacking arm between your upper arm and flank.

bunkai2.name: [ES] Nihon Hiki Uke
bunkai2.attack: [ES] Chudan Oi Zuki + Jodan Gyaku Zuki.
bunkai2.footwork: [ES] One step back or two Sayu Tenshin.
bunkai2.notes: [ES] With the hand/arm of the second attack, you lock up the other arm. Optionally apply pressure with the big toe on the forefoot [Kori].

bunkai3.name: [ES] Tora Guchi
bunkai3.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin to Neko Ashi Dachi, then step out. After the push, pull back the rear foot.
bunkai3.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. [Kinteki] and carotid artery/Adam's apple [Matsukaze]/[Nodo Botoke].
bunkai3.notes: [ES] Intercept attack early and execute with Muchimi.

saifa.title: [ES] Saifa Bunkai
saifa.description: [ES] Means something like 'destructive strikes'. 'Sai' means, as in Gekisai, 'destroy'. 'Fa' means, among other things, 'strike'. Typical for kata Saifa are the many striking techniques, such as uraken uchi, tettsui uchi, and haito uchi. Saifa is the first classical koryu kata.

bunkai1.name: [ES] Hazushi Waza + Otoshi Uke + Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai1.defense: [ES] 1. Hazushi Waza (release technique). 2. Shotei Otoshi Uke.
bunkai1.footwork: [ES] 45° step in and turn into Heiko Dachi, then step in or back to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai1.notes: [ES] When stepping in, press the knuckles of the grabbed hand/arm against the opponent's forearm to weaken their grip (maintain pressure from the start). When pulling free (Hazushi Waza), keep your arms close to your body. After the Otoshi Uke, grab the arm (don't grab immediately). The block can also be executed in Osae or Nagashi form.

bunkai2.name: [ES] Sukui Uke + Shotei Gedan Harai Uke + Hiza Ate + Mae Geri
bunkai2.defense: [ES] Sukui Uke + Shotei Gedan Harai Uke.
bunkai2.footwork: [ES] From Heiko Dachi back with Suri Ashi to Heiko Sanchin Dachi.
bunkai2.notes: [ES] With the Sukui Uke, the other hand is used as protection. The attacker must immediately retract the Mae Geri. When the attacker turns their torso sideways after retracting the Mae Geri, make the Mae Geri to the flank.

bunkai3.name: [ES] (Morote Hiki Uke +) Heiko Zuki
bunkai3.footwork: [ES] One foot back + forward Suri Ashi or Ayumi Ashi (depending on distance). In case of large, strong opponent: two Sayu Tenshin.
bunkai3.notes: [ES] The Morote Nukite Zuki and Morote Oshi are executed as much as possible in one movement.

bunkai4.name: [ES] (Morote) Gedan Furi Uchi
bunkai4.counterAttack: [ES] Morote Gedan Furi Uchi + Kubi Nage.
bunkai4.footwork: [ES] Kotai Ayumi Ashi possibly turn away when throwing.
bunkai4.notes: [ES] Grab at the ears or at the jaw and hair.

bunkai5.name: [ES] Tettsui Uchi + TsukamiHiki + Ura Zuki + Jodan Gyaku 'Zuki'
bunkai5.counterAttack: [ES] Tettsui Uchi + Tsukkamihiki + Ura Zuki + Jodan (Gyaku) Oshi.
bunkai5.footwork: [ES] Tai Sabaki, then step out for the Ura Zuki and possibly step through for the push (Ayumi Ashi).
bunkai5.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. fontanel [Shomon] (Tettsui Uchi) + nose (Ura Zuki) + possibly Eye [Gansei] (Oshi).
bunkai5.notes: [ES] Keep the arm round and close to the body during the low block (don't 'scoop').

bunkai6.name: [ES] Haito Uchi
bunkai6.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin to Neko Ashi Dachi.
bunkai6.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. Floating rib/kidneys [Ushiro Denko] or neck [Keichu].
bunkai6.notes: [ES] In the Kata, the Haito Uchi is a Chudan technique.

bunkai7.name: [ES] Tora Guchi
bunkai7.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin to Neko Ashi Dachi, then step out. After the push, pull back the rear foot.
bunkai7.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. [Kinteki] and carotid artery/Adam's apple [Matsukaze]/[Nodo Botoke].
bunkai7.notes: [ES] Intercept attack early and execute with Muchimi.

seiyunchin.title: [ES] Seiyunchin Bunkai
seiyunchin.description: [ES] Literally means 'to unbalance in battle'. This kata is the only kaishu kata without kicking techniques and emphasizes the formation of strong, stable stances. The bunkai kumite (applications) consist of various wrestling and throwing techniques that are very suitable for close combat. Exam material for sankyu (third kyu, brown belt) and above.

bunkai1.name: [ES] Morote Gedan Harai Uke
bunkai1.counterAttack: [ES] Hiza Geri or Mae Geri (front or back leg).
bunkai1.footwork: [ES] First step forward, then diagonally back to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai1.notes: [ES] It is important to first weaken the opponent's grip (double upward thrust). The meaning of dropping into Shiko Dachi is to learn to use your weight as power in release techniques.

bunkai2.name: [ES] Sukui Uke + Hiki Uke + Hira Nukite Zuki
bunkai2.footwork: [ES] One foot back, then step out to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai2.notes: [ES] With Nukite Zuki, first make contact, then apply force.

bunkai3.name: [ES] Hojo Oshi
bunkai3.counterAttack: [ES] Chudan Nakadaka Ippon Ken Zuki + Morote Shotei Hojo Oshi
bunkai3.footwork: [ES] Turn into Heiko Sanchin Dachi + Suri Ashi forward during the push.

bunkai4.name: [ES] Chudan Hiji Ate
bunkai4.footwork: [ES] One foot back, then the other forward.

bunkai5.name: [ES] Hojo Uke + Gedan Harai Uchi
bunkai5.notes: [ES] From Shodan level, these bunkai and the next (with Gedan Barai) are performed as one continuous technique.

bunkai6.name: [ES] Hari Uke
bunkai6.defense: [ES] Kaishu Jodan Age Uke (+ grab) + Gedan Shotei Harai Uke (+ grab)
bunkai6.footwork: [ES] One foot back, then the other foot to the opponent's supporting leg and then Tai Sabaki. For lighter karateka, two times Sayu Tenshin.
bunkai6.notes: [ES] For safety, the throw is performed with a large turning movement. In a self-defense situation, with a not too heavy opponent, the throw is short and the head is...

bunkai7.name: [ES] Chudan Yoko Shotei Uke / Jodan Uchi Uke > Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai7.attack: [ES] Chudan Gyaku Zuki + Jodan Jun Zuki
bunkai7.defense: [ES] Otoshi Uke (+ grab) + Jodan Uchi Uke.
bunkai7.counterAttack: [ES] (optionally Ashi Barai with front leg +) Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai7.footwork: [ES] One foot back. Optionally slip in with Jodan Uraken Uchi.
bunkai7.notes: [ES] Only make the Ashi Barai if the distance allows.

bunkai8.name: [ES] (Doji Uke +) Age Zuki + Jodan Uraken Uchi + Gedan Harai Uke (Uchi)
bunkai8.counterAttack: [ES] Age Zuki + Jodan Uraken Uchi + Gedan Harai Uchi.
bunkai8.footwork: [ES] One foot back, then step out to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai8.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. jaw [Mikazuki] (Age Zuki) + [Jinchu] (Jodan Uraken Uchi) + [Kinteki] (Gedan Harai Uchi).
bunkai8.notes: [ES] Advanced students should also practice this against Chudan Zuki + Gedan Zuki or Mae Geri (application of Doji Uke).

bunkai9.name: [ES] Hiji Age
bunkai9.defense: [ES] Hiji Age + Ushiro Hiji Ate (simultaneously) then turn out to Kamae.
bunkai9.footwork: [ES] After being grabbed, step forward to 'Neko Ashi Dachi'.
bunkai9.notes: [ES] If the grip is too strong, first attack a Kyusho. For example, with a backward headbutt, kick to the foot, strike to the groin, etc.

bunkai10.name: [ES] Otoshi Uke + Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai10.notes: [ES] The block and the strike follow each other smoothly.

bunkai11.name: [ES] Morote Kuri Uke
bunkai11.defense: [ES] Morote Kuri Uke as a release technique.
bunkai11.footwork: [ES] Step back and fall into Neko Ashi Dachi.
bunkai11.notes: [ES] As in the kata, it is important that the forearms come together well above the opponent's arms.

bunkai12.name: [ES] Chudan Oi Zuki > Chudan Yoko Uke + grab wrist > Gedan Harai Uke (Uchi)
bunkai12.defense: [ES] Chudan Yoko Uke + immediately continue to grab the wrist.
bunkai12.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin, 30 degree turn + foot switch (back-in) to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai12.notes: [ES] When moving to Shiko Dachi, turn in such a way that you can hit the groin unimpeded.

shisochin.title: [ES] Shisochin Bunkai
shisochin.description: [ES] Literally means 'fight in 4 directions'. Another translation is '4 doors'. The word door is a symbolic word for the place where a potential opponent can attack, can 'enter'. The kata contains a typical attack combination, which is performed in four directions. Exam material for ikkyu (first kyu, brown belt) and above.

bunkai1.name: [ES] Chudan Nukite Zuki
bunkai1.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. solar plexus [Suigetsu]) or carotid artery [Matsukaze].
bunkai1.notes: [ES] An attack to Suigetsu will only be realistic with a large strength difference and strong hands.

bunkai2.name: [ES] Morote Sukui Uke + 'Morote Gedan Harai Uke'
bunkai2.defense: [ES] Morete Sukui Uke + grab + 'Morete Gedan Harai Uke'.
bunkai2.counterAttack: [ES] Mae Geri or Hiza Geri with rear leg.
bunkai2.footwork: [ES] Step back to avoid the attack and to grab the opponent's thumbs or wrists.
bunkai2.notes: [ES] The same bunkai can also be performed if both wrists are grabbed.

bunkai3.name: [ES] Chudan Ura Kake Uke (Doji Uke) + Gyaku Te
bunkai3.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin, then turn in with the outer leg and then stretch it to unbalance the opponent. Then turn to Shiko Dachi for Otoshi Hiji Ate.
bunkai3.notes: [ES] Advanced students should perform the block and Gyaku Te in one movement. The technique in question does not have a name of its own but is named after the application. Namely: Gyaku Te, which is a collective name for locks, grips, etc.

bunkai4.name: [ES] Hiji Age / Ushiro Hiji Ate
bunkai4.attack: [ES] Grab from behind, one arm trapped.
bunkai4.defense: [ES] Jodan Ushiro Zuki + Ushiro Hiji Ate.
bunkai4.notes: [ES] If the hold is too strong, it is better to attack a Kyusho first. For example, the point [Koin] (on the foot) with the heel or the testicles [Kinteki] with the hand.

bunkai5.name: [ES] Nagashi Shotei Gedan Harai Uke + Shotei Zuki
bunkai5.footwork: [ES] Step in and turn away in one movement.
bunkai5.notes: [ES] The upward effect in the movement helps uproot the opponent. In the case of an attack on the eyes, the opponent's hand is more difficult to see coming because it comes from below.

bunkai6.name: [ES] Hiki Uke + Mae Geri + Chudan Hiji Ate
bunkai6.counterAttack: [ES] Gedan Mae Geri + Chudan Hiji Ate + Nihon Nukite.
bunkai6.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin. After Mae Geri move forward into Zenkutsu Dachi.
bunkai6.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. [Kinteki] (Gedan Mae Geri) + [Ganka] (Chudan Hiji Ate) + Eyes [Gansei] (Nihon Nukite).

bunkai7.name: [ES] Otoshi Uke + Hiji Ate
bunkai7.notes: [ES] The attack must be intercepted early and pressed inward and (then) downward.

bunkai8.name: [ES] Morote Hiji Ate
bunkai8.footwork: [ES] One foot back for stability then step in.
bunkai8.vitalPoints: [ES] E.g. collarbone or chest (Otoshi Hiji Ate).
bunkai8.notes: [ES] Note: For the execution of Morote Hiji Age, the hands are raised and spread open.

bunkai9.name: [ES] Doji Uke
bunkai9.footwork: [ES] Sayu Tenshin to Neko Ashi Dachi, then forward Suri Ashi in Neko Ashi Dachi.

sanseru.title: [ES] Sanseru Bunkai
sanseru.description: [ES] Sanseru literally means '36 hands'. The name refers to Buddhist symbolism: 36 is the symbolic multiplication of 6 × 6. The first 6 stands for eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. The second 6 symbolizes color, voice, taste, smell, touch, and justice. This kata is exam material for nidan (second dan) and above. The bunkai focus on close-range defense, joint locks, and takedowns.

bunkai1.name: [ES] Chudan Yoko Uke > Chudan Gyaku Zuki
bunkai1.footwork: [ES] Right foot Sayu Tenshin with a turn to left Heiko Sanchin Dachi.

bunkai2.name: [ES] Kakate Uke > Hazushi Waza
bunkai2.attack: [ES] Kote Dori - left hand grabs right wrist
bunkai2.defense: [ES] Kake Uke + Hazushi Waza with the left hand on the wrist/forearm.
bunkai2.footwork: [ES] Step in with right to weaken the grip; step back with right to add force while performing Hazushi Waza.
bunkai2.notes: [ES] When performing Hazushi Waza, keep the arm close to the body, let the fingers go upward and then spread, then 'cut' with the knife hand.

bunkai3.name: [ES] Ashi Dori > Mae Geri > Kansetsu Geri
bunkai3.defense: [ES] Ashi Dori (right Shotei Uchi Gedan Harai Uke)
bunkai3.counterAttack: [ES] Chudan Ashi Dori + right Kin Geri + Kansetsu Geri Nage or Gedan Fumikomi.
bunkai3.footwork: [ES] Remain standing, turn the body away (Tai Sabaki in place).
bunkai3.notes: [ES] After the groin kick, turn the right hand and place the right thumb into the inner thigh muscle (quadriceps). After the kick, keep the knee inside the thigh and place the foot above the other knee. Use a lever motion for the takedown.

bunkai4.name: [ES] Mae Hiji Ate > Gedan Gyaku Zuki > Kansetsu Geri
bunkai4.attack: [ES] 1. Right Chudan Oi Zuki. 2. Left Gedan Gyaku Zuki.
bunkai4.defense: [ES] 1. Left Chudan Shotei Osae/Otoshi Uke. 2. Right Gedan Harai Uke.
bunkai4.counterAttack: [ES] 1. Right Chudan Hiji Ate + Left Gedan Gyaku Zuki + Right Kansetsu Geri.
bunkai4.footwork: [ES] 1. Foot switch (Uke + Hiji Ate). Kotai Suri Ashi (Uke) + left Sayu Tenshin (Kansetsu Geri).

bunkai5.name: [ES] Gedan Seiken Juji Uke
bunkai5.footwork: [ES] Right foot steps back into low Shiko Dachi.

bunkai6.name: [ES] Gedan Kaishu Juji Uke
bunkai6.footwork: [ES] Right foot steps back into low Shiko Dachi.

bunkai7.name: [ES] Mawashi Uke > Awase Zuki
bunkai7.attack: [ES] 1. Right Gedan Mae Geri. 2. Right Jodan Oi Zuki.
bunkai7.defense: [ES] 1. Gedan Shotei Harai Uke + grab. 2. Open hand Age Uke + grab (Gyaku Sukui Uke)
bunkai7.counterAttack: [ES] Awase Zuki Nage (combined punch and throw)
bunkai7.footwork: [ES] Step in with Sayu Tenshin turn (45 degrees)

bunkai8.name: [ES] Kami Kiri No Kamae
bunkai8.attack: [ES] Right Chudan Gyaku Zuki + Left Jodan Oi Zuki
bunkai8.defense: [ES] Left Chudan Yoko Ko Uke + Right Age Ko Uke
bunkai8.counterAttack: [ES] Double finger thrust + double palm strike + leg grab throw + downward palm strike.
bunkai8.footwork: [ES] First return to Heiko Sanchin (during Yoko Ko Uke), then step in to Shiko Dachi (Age Ko Uke)

history.title: Historia
history.origins-desc: El Karate Goju-Ryu fue desarrollado a principios del siglo XX por Chojun Miyagi en Okinawa, Japón. El nombre 'Goju' proviene del principio 'duro-suave' de las artes marciales chinas tradicionales, reflejando la doble naturaleza del sistema: combina técnicas de golpeo duras con movimientos más suaves y circulares tanto para el ataque como para la defensa.
history.development-desc: El desarrollo y la difusión del Goju Ryu por todo el mundo
history.lineage-desc: Los principales maestros y sus contribuciones al estilo

subsections.early-history-desc: Los orígenes del Goju Ryu se remontan a las artes marciales chinas y su integración en la cultura okinawense.
subsections.miyagi-era-desc: El desarrollo y sistematización del estilo Goju Ryu por Chojun Miyagi en las décadas de 1920 y 1930.
subsections.post-war-desc: La expansión y desarrollo del Goju Ryu después de la Segunda Guerra Mundial.
subsections.modern-era-desc: El desarrollo actual y la difusión mundial del Goju Ryu.
